awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium:  Collaborative Research: Numerical Algebraic Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Many basic physical principles, like conservation of mass or momentum for a fluid, are captured mathematically as systems of algebraic differential equations.  Simplifying and solving these systems (which means reducing the number or complexity of the equations, and finding inputs that satisfy all equations) are fundamental to applications in many areas, including cellular biology, approximation for chemical reaction systems, combinatorics, and analysis.  The theoretical and algorithmic study of such systems spans more than a century, using three methods: purely symbolic, numerical, and hybrid symbolic-numeric.  

Symbolic methods (the quadratic formula being the simplest example) give the strongest guarantees of reliability, at a high (even exorbitant) cost in computational time and memory, since the same algorithm solves both mathematically hard and easy instances.  Numerical methods (the basis for computational simulation) allow small errors or approximations for speed; small intermediate errors produce corrupted outputs on singular and ill-conditioned (that is, nearly singular) input instances. In this project, a hybrid symbolic-numeric approach will be developed. Hybrid algorithms are more adaptive and have lower complexity than symbolic algorithms, and can avoid the errors of numerical algorithms.

In more technical detail, the three investigators apply existing and develop new methods of symbolic-numeric computation and differential algebra, producing algorithms that run on all inputs. They bring together existing methods of numerical algebraic geometry and software packages, such as Bertini, with recent theoretical results in differential algebra that provide upper bounds needed for guaranteed results. New near-optimal root isolation techniques are developed, implemented, and applied to solve systems of differential equations with finitely many solutions.  The work spans from theory to producing practical tools.

As part of this project the three investigators mentor and train students in symbolic and numeric computation at CUNY (noted for serving minority and low-income students) and NYU, and more broadly in New York City and Long Island, by activities ranging from  developing a Symbolic-Numeric Computing course for graduate students at the Computer Science program of the CUNY Graduate Center and NYU, to advising high school students in projects.

por.por_cntn:
Differential equations are used to model a variety of natural phenomena. Symbolic methods and numeric methods are the two main approaches to the analysis of differential equations. Symbolic methods provide the strongest guarantees of reliability, but typically at a very high cost in computational time and memory, since the same algorithm solves both mathematically hard and easy instances. Numerical methods allow small errors or approximations for speed; small intermediate errors can result in corrupted outputs, and reliability of numerical methods is a substantial challenge.

In this award, we made substantial progress in addressing the efficiency challenge of symbolic computation and reliability challenge of numeric computation applied to differential equations. We achieved this by developing new theory that, with the user-specified probability of correctness, solves the same problem but significantly more efficiently. A key approach in our hybrid method is the reduction of the variables to solve for by replacing some of the variables with random numbers. How these random numbers are chosen is provided by our new theory.

A technique we developed for ODE systems produces a system of polynomial equations an analysis of solutions of which answers questions about the ODE system. Typically, a key step in analyzing solutions is root isolation for polynomials in one variable. This is a classical problem of high independent importance: this oldest problem of mathematics and computational mathematics has been their central subject for about four millennia since Sumerian times until the middle of XIX century. It regained importance with the advance of computer technology, due to applications to signal processing, control, financial mathematics, geometric modeling, and computer algebra. The area has been investigated for centuries and very intensively in last decades.

We made substantial progress by applying novel techniques to design and analysis of root-finding based on subdivision method, known to be nearly optimal for polynomials given in a monomial basis - with their coefficients, and being a champion for root-finding in a disc on the complex plane with a relatively small number of roots. We devised new fast methods for root-counting in a disc on the complex plane, in particular for deciding whether such a disc contains any root, which is the bottleneck stage of the customary subdivision process. 

Moreover, we discovered two additional techniques for decreasing the overall number of exclusion tests: by applying some novel non-costly inclusion tests, which certify that a disc contains a root if it does, and by narrowing the search region for the roots to the union of at most d narrow annuli on the complex plane for a degree d polynomial. According to our extensive tests with customary test polynomials, the latter technique alone enabled significant acceleration of the current real root-finder by A. Kobel, F. Rouillier, and M. Sagraloff (ISSAC 2016), which is user's choice algorithm.

In sharp contrast to the most celebrated recent advance by Becker et al in ISSAC 2016 and JSC 2018, as well other known efficient root-finders, our novel algorithms remain as fast where the input is a black box polynomial - represented by a black box subroutine for its evaluation. This remarkable feature of our algorithm enabled dramatic acceleration where the evaluation is fast, which is the case for various highly important classes such as sparse polynomials or Mandelbrot?s polynomials, defined recursively in compressed form.

The results of our work have been published in journals and refereed conference proceedings and have been presented at the leading conferences and workshops in this field such as ISSAC, CASC, MACIS, and SIAM conferences on Applied Algebraic Geometry and Linear Algebra. We co-organized the ISSAC 2018 conference. Pre-print versions of research articles supported by this award are available for free public use. We have implemented algorithms based on our theory in a variety of computational platforms, including a Maple Cloud web application, and made them publicly available. Our presentation at the ISSAC 2021 conference was recognized with the Distinguished Software Demonstration award, and our poster at the SIAM Applied Algebraic Geometry conference in 2019 received the Best Poster award. 

This award provided support to eight Ph.D. students in the form of mentorship, research assistantship, and travel support. Four of these students have defended their dissertations and are pursuing their careers. The award supported four postdoctoral scholars. Four high-school students were mentored, two of whom presented the resulting research at three science and engineering fairs in New York and New Jersey and received honors at the fairs/advanced to the fair finals.
